In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.   During the 2010 country programming mission, the Government of Bangladesh asked 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide capacity development technical assistance (TA) 
to the Local Government Engineering Department (LGED) to further advance its commitment to 
gender equality and women’s empowerment in rural infrastructure initiatives. More specifically, 
the TA will improve the capacity of the LGED to implement its gender equity action plan by 
developing a more standardized approach to promote women’s participation in and benefit from 
rural infrastructure development. The TA is consistent with the strategic priorities identified in 
the  country  strategy  and  program,  2006–2010.1 ADB  and  the  government  reached  an 
agreement  on  the  project’s  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation  arrangements,  cost, 
financing arrangements, and terms of reference for consulting services.2 The TA design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  LGED’s mission is to develop and manage rural infrastructure to increase farm and non-
farm production, create jobs, improve socioeconomic conditions, promote local governance, and 
act as an agent of change at the local level. Its implementation approach for rural infrastructure 
projects  underscores  community  participation,  local  governance,  and  creating  community 
employment and income benefits. This includes innovative elements that aim to foster women’s 
participation in both project and local governance activities. Innovations include setting targets 
for women’s employment in construction, requiring equal pay for women for work of equal value, 
and promoting women-friendly working conditions. Where infrastructure initiatives have included 
upgrading of rural markets, these have included shops for women’s businesses in women’s 
market sections and reserved space on market platforms for women traders. There have also 
been initiatives to promote more effective participation in local decision making by women 
elected to reserved seats.  
 
3.  LGED implements a large number of rural infrastructure projects. In June 2010, for 
example, it had 53 rural infrastructure projects. Most of these projects are financed by the 
government, but some are supported by development partners. LGED’s rural infrastructure and 
water management projects have been innovative in their approach to addressing governance 
issues  and  to  increasing  the  participation  of  women  in  local  councils  and  community 
organizations. But further improvement in the capacity of local government organizations and 
the involvement of women in decision making is needed. LGED needs a standardized approach 
to foster women’s participation in and benefit from the rural infrastructure program. It also needs 
to  pilot  additional  measures  for  improving  engagement  of  women  in  development  and 
management of rural infrastructure.  
 
4.  LGED has incorporated innovative elements into a number of recently completed and 
current infrastructure projects that encourage women’s participation in local governance and 
benefit from improvements in rural infrastructure. However, there is no consolidated source of 
information  on  the  extent  to  which  LGED  rural  infrastructure  projects  are  incorporating 
innovations that have been successful in previous projects, nor is there a consolidated source of 
guidance for future projects.

2   
 
5.  To  strengthen  its  role  in fostering  the  participation  of  women  in  rural  infrastructure 
development, LGED needs to (i) develop an agreed set of elements of women’s participation in 
the decision making and planning of local governments on rural infrastructure, and (ii) pilot a 
performance-based approach to women’s participation in local governments.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The impact of the TA will be enhanced women’s participation in local governance and 
the  local  economy.  The  outcome  will  be  better  knowledge,  tools,  and  gender-related 
performance criteria used by LGED. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  This TA aims to consolidate and build on the innovations achieved by LGED through its 
rural infrastructure projects. The TA will also explore the potential to apply LGED’s experience 
with  performance-based  approaches  to  local  government  practices  related  to  women’s 
participation at the Union Parishad (local government institution) level.   
 
8.  The TA will consist of the following two outputs: 
 
9.  Output  1:  Improved  LGED  capacity  to  engage  women  in  rural  infrastructure 
initiatives. The TA will review innovations that have been undertaken to determine the extent to 
which they have been incorporated across rural infrastructure projects and to consider which 
approaches  to  implementation  have  been more  effective. The review  will  identify  a  set of 
minimum elements to be included in rural infrastructure projects (including those financed by the 
government and supported by development partners) to enhance women’s participation and 
benefit, in order to create a more standardized approach. This component will result in better 
tools and initiatives in the design of LGED’s rural infrastructure projects for a more consistent 
approach to women’s participation and benefit.   
 
10.  This learning- and capacity-development component provides an opportunity to draw on 
LGED  experience  in  a  more  structured  way.  This  component  will  be  pursued,  in  close 
collaboration with LGED, to ensure that the focus is realistic and practical and that there is 
ownership of the outputs. Three elements of this collaboration that will be particularly important 
are: 
 
(i)  collaboration with a subcommittee of the LGED Gender Forum to gain their guidance 
and support for this component and to promote the practicality and legitimacy of the 
outputs; 
(ii)  liaison with the LGED monitoring unit, which has an important role in tracking LGED 
project performance, including in relation to gender equity; and  
(iii)  workshop with LGED rural infrastructure project directors to discuss and refine the 
proposed list of minimum elements on women’s participation and benefit and to 
make recommendations to the Gender Forum so that it can finalize an agreed set of 
minimum elements.

3 
11.  Output  2:  Performance-based  approach  to  improve  women’s  participation  in 
Union Parishad structures and processes. This component will adapt an approach used in 
LGED urban infrastructure projects supported by ADB that uses a set of agreed performance 
indicators to give access to infrastructure investments. The performance criteria in this case will 
focus specifically on women’s participation in Union Parishad structures and processes. The 
performance criteria used in the pilot will be finalized through consultations with participating 
unions to ensure their ownership and commitment. The provisions of the Local Government 
(Union Parishad) Act, 2009 that are relevant to women’s participation will also be considered, so 
that the pilot can contribute to implementation of this act.  
 
12.  Twenty Union Parishads will have access to funds for infrastructure development, if they 
meet  the  performance  standards  for  women’s  participation  in  local  governments.  For  this 
purpose, $1 million has been set aside in the Sustainable Rural Infrastructure Improvement 
Project (SRIIP)3 to which this TA is related. The Union Parishads in the pilot that meet the 
agreed  performance  standards  will  receive  funds  of  up  to  $45,000  each  for  infrastructure 
activities, such as upgrading village roads, building bridges or culverts, upgrading rural market 
structures, and installing solar panels to provide lighting for rural markets. The Union Parishads 
will manage the infrastructure investment with technical support from LGED.  
13.  Capacity-building support will be provided to participating Union Parishads. The outcome 
of this approach will be tracked and assessed as a pilot for possible follow-up in future LGED 
infrastructure projects. Results will also be shared with other development partners working with 
local governments, in particular the World Bank, in light of the Local Governance Support 
Program, which is being implemented nationwide and also incorporates performance standards. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.   The total cost of the TA is estimated at $575,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB. 
The Government of Bangladesh will cover the remaining $75,000 equivalent by providing office 
space, counterpart staff, and communication support. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 4 years, and could start implementation on 1 June 
2011, before the loan consultants are in place. ADB will recruit individual consultants for the TA 
following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Disbursements will be made in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (May 2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
16.   As  agreed  by  LGED,  ADB  will  be  the  executing  agency,  while  LGED  will  be  the 
implementing agency, with support from the LGED Gender Forum. The LGED Gender Forum 
will support and guide the implementation of component 1. As the Gender Forum is a large 
group, which includes senior management of LGED and project directors from all sections, the 
SRIIP  project  director  and  ADB  will  consult  with  the  LGED  chief  engineer  and  identify  a 
subcommittee. The subcommittee will consist of a representative of LGED senior management 
(as chair), the SRIIP project director (as coordinator), 3–4 other project directors with rural 
                                                
3 ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan to the People’s 
Republic of Bangladesh for Sustainable Rural Infrastructure Improvement Project. Manila.

4   
infrastructure projects, the LGED implementation monitoring unit, and a representative of ADB 
as an invitee. 
 
17.  ADB will recruit national consultants and administrative staff in consultation with LGED. 
Required consultants include a team leader (42 person-months, 36 full-time and then 6 months 
intermittent), an analyst for component 1 (full-time for 8 months), a field supervisor (full-time for 
48  months),  four  field  workers  (48  months  each).  An  office  manager-cum-accountant  (48 
person-months) and an office support worker (48 person-months) are also required.   
 
18.  The team leader will manage the consultants and administrative staff and be responsible 
for the implementation and outputs of both components of the TA. The team leader will report to 
both ADB and the SRIIP project director on the achievement of milestones and implementation 
progress. 
 
19.  The areas in which the pilot will be implemented should be reasonably accessible to 
LGED’s subproject offices to facilitate supervision and monitoring. The pilot unions should be 
identified in clusters to maximize the resources available for capacity-building support. The 
participating unions should provide a reasonable basis on which to judge whether the approach 
merits wider replication, and should therefore include a range of conditions. Unions should have 
equitable access to assistance. The pilot should thus exclude unions that have previously 
received  support  through  other  programs  for  capacity  development  related  to  women’s 
participation. 
20.  An initial step for each component will be the formulation of an implementation plan. For 
component 1, the implementation plan will be formulated within the first month in consultation 
with the LGED Gender Forum Sub-Committee. For component 2, the implementation plan will 
be based on several steps taken in the first phase of the component and be finalized in 
consultation with the SRIIP project director and ADB before the end of the sixth month. A work 
plan for the first 6 months, showing the steps toward this point, will be prepared in the first 
month. 
 
21.  TA progress will be monitored by ADB and the SRIIP project director through consultant 
reports, periodic consultation, and review missions. The administrative reports (progress reports 
and work plans) are to be submitted on the agreed schedule (with technical reports attached). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION   
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Bangladesh to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Support to Local Government Engineering Department in Institutionalizing Women’s Benefits 
from Rural Infrastructure Initiatives, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

2.  Team leader (42 person-months). The team leader will be a senior social development 
and gender specialist with demonstrated experience in working with government organizations at 
the local and national level to better reach and serve women and with demonstrated experience in 
managing a project team. The specialist will have at least 10 years of experience directly relevant 
to this assignment and postgraduate qualifications in a relevant discipline (or additional equivalent 
experience). As team leader, the specialist will provide overall substantive leadership to the TA 
team and overall management of the TA and outputs. Responsibilities and activities will include:   
 
(i)  Management of the subproject office and the subproject team: 
(a)  liaising with LGED about the overall project and establishing the Gender 
Forum Sub-Committee to guide the project (particularly component 1); 
(b)  procuring goods and services for the TA operation; 
(c)  preparing progress reports, work plans, and budgets;

10  Appendix 3 
 
(d)  holding  regular  team  meetings  to  review  progress  and  discuss  plans, 
requirements, and issues; and 
(e)  managing  consultant  and  administrative  staff  (work  plans,  hours,  leave, 
remuneration, roles and/or coordination, etc.).  
(ii)    Guidance for the component 1 study and outputs: 
(a)  supporting  the  analyst  in  preparing  the  implementation  plan  for  this 
component, including identifying innovative elements to be covered by the 
study and the study methodology; 
(b)  supervising  the  analyst’s  execution  of  the  study,  analyzing  findings, 
conclusions; 
(c)  supervising and supporting the analyst in the preparation of component 1 
outputs; and 
(d)  supporting the analyst in consultations with the LGED Gender Forum Sub-
Committee and in the workshop with LGED. 
(iii)    Overall responsibility for component 2 work planning and implementation, including: 
(a)  preparing a work plan for the first 6 months, and an implementation plan for 
the rest of the subproject period, based on the work in the first 6 months;  
(b)  recruiting support personnel, training them, guiding them in preparing their 
work plan, and monitoring their activities; 
(c)  planning  a  participatory  process  and  leading  workshop  discussions  with 
participating  Union  Parishads  to  reach  agreement  on  the  governance 
improvements to be addressed in the pilot and the appropriate performance 
standards; 
(d)  guiding staff in reviewing the experiences of other projects and organizations 
to  identify  useful  approaches  and  good  practices  (including  RIIP-II 
approaches, nongovernmental organization approaches); 
(e)  designing  and  supervising  the  baseline  assessment  of  the  participating 
Union Parishads, as part of a needs assessment of requirements to achieve 
performance standards; 
(f)  developing a capacity-building approach on the basis of the above, with an 
emphasis on coaching, but also possibly including workshop training, peer 
learning, etc.;  
(g)  training, guiding, and supporting field staff in implementing the capacity-
building activities; continuing to monitor the quality of delivery and the needs 
of Union Parishads; and revising materials and strategy accordingly; 
(h)  designing  and  supervising  the  annual  assessment  process  against 
performance criteria; and 
(i)  preparing  an  in-depth  assessment  of  the  pilot  in  the  last  year  of  the 
assignment. 
 
3.  Analyst  (8  person-months).  The  analyst  will  be  a  senior  gender  and  development 
specialist with demonstrated experience, skills, and expertise in ensuring attention to women’s 
interests  and  needs  in  project  design  and  implementation,  preferably  in  relation  to  rural 
development or infrastructure. The analyst will have at least 10 years of experience in gender and 
development work at the project level, and will have demonstrated skills in research and analysis 
and in preparing clearly written concise documents. The analyst will implement component 1, with 
the support and guidance of the team leader. Responsibilities and activities will include: 
(i)  developing a relationship with the LGED Gender Forum Sub-Committee for this TA, 
and with the LGED monitoring unit; 
(ii)  preparing an implementation plan for this component, including the identification of 
innovative elements to be covered by the study and the study methodology; 
(iii)  executing the study and preparing a concise working document of the findings;

Appendix 3  11 
(iv)  further analyzing the findings to identify a list of minimum elements for women’s 
participation and benefit for future projects; 
(v)  liaising with the Gender Forum Sub-Committee about the study findings and the 
proposed list of minimum elements for women’s participation and benefit; 
(vi)  designing and leading a workshop with LGED rural infrastructure project directors to 
review and discuss the list of minimal elements and reach conclusions about what 
should be recommended to LGED; 
(vii)  preparing practical and concise guidance materials based on the findings of the 
study to be used in conjunction with the list of minimum elements for planning and 
implementation of rural infrastructure projects; and 
(viii)  preparing a reproduction and dissemination strategy for these materials. 
 
4.  Field  supervisor  (48  person-months). The field supervisor will have experience  and 
expertise as a field worker in issues of gender equality and women’s participation, preferably in 
relation  to  local  government  functions,  and  in  organizing  and  supporting  a  small  team. 
Responsibilities and activities will include: 
(i)  organizing the schedule and logistics for the field workers; 
(ii)  liaising with participating Union Parishads about scheduling, progress, needs, etc.; 
(iii)  providing back up and assistance to field workers in coaching and training activities 
with participating Union Parishads; 
(iv)  collaborating  with  the  team  leader  to  organize  and  conduct  workshops, 
consultations, peer learning events, etc.; 
(v)  collaborating with and supporting the team leader to develop coaching and capacity-
building materials and to monitor their usefulness; and 
(vi)  providing other support as requested to the team leader to undertake the baseline 
assessment, review relevant experience, conduct annual assessments, etc. 
 
5.  Field workers (192 person-months). Field workers will have experience and expertise in 
issues of gender equality and women’s participation, preferably in relation to local government 
functions. In particular, field workers should have a demonstrated ability to support individuals and 
organizations in accepting new ideas and practices in relation to women’s participation in decision 
making. Responsibilities and activities will include: 
(i)  providing support to participating Union Parishads at the union level, working with 
the coaching materials and guidelines developed for this component; 
(ii)  traveling  regularly  between  participating  Union  Parishads  and  between  Union 
Parishads and the project office; 
(iii)  participating in other forms of training and capacity support, including workshops, 
exchange visits, etc.; 
(iv)  providing other support as requested by the field supervisor and team leader in 
implementing  component  2  (and  possibly  in  supporting  implementation  of  the 
component 1 study, if time allows). 
 
6.  Office manager-cum-accountant (48 months). This consultant will have well-rounded 
experience as an office manager and be capable of undertaking administrative, logistical, and 
accounting functions and of working collaboratively. Responsibilities and activities will include (i) 
providing  administrative  assistance  to  the  team  leader;  (ii)  providing  logistical  support  for  all 
members of the team (including, arrangements for workshops, meetings of the Gender Forum Sub-
Committee, printing of documents, transport, etc.); and (iii) maintaining accounts and financial 
reports on subproject activities.
